awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Expanding Access: Furthering a Network of Diversity-Focused Programs in the Physical Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Access Network, a project aimed at substantially improving equity and inclusion in the physical sciences. Formed in 2014, Access is a national network that brings together nine programs that all leverage best practices for serving underrepresented students in Physics and other physical sciences.  This award would expand the network from 9 to 15 sites and begin to scale up network activities by identifying and recruiting new sites (particularly from Minority Serving Institutions), building capacity within new sites through an "onboarding workshop", intensively mentoring new sites in their first year, maintaining existing Access Network activities to support a strong intersite-community, and planning and conducting internal and external evaluation to document successes and support sites' sustainability. These activities will enhance the capacity of the network to support both old and new sites, thus allowing the network to reach considerably more students in more effective ways.

Access sites are modeled on the nationally-recognized Compass Project at UC Berkeley. Driven by a set of shared principles (e.g., student voice, authentic disciplinary engagement) and a suite of programmatic offerings (e.g., mentorship, model building courses, community events, early research opportunities), each site is tailored to the needs of its unique population, ranging from a large number of Deaf and hard of hearing students at the Rochester Institute of Technology to Black commuter students at Chicago State University. The network supports each site by providing relevant expertise, community support, mentored leadership opportunities, and a set of shared resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
What is The Access Network? The Access Network (https://accessnetwork.org/) is an organization that supports vibrant interactions among students, staff, and faculty advocating for equity in the physical sciences. The Network connects nine student-led, equity-oriented, university-based programs (called "sites"). The primary goals of Access are to model a STEM community that values equity, student leadership, and holistic support, as well as to provide shared resources and expertise related to social justice work and education. Each Access site offers a set of support programs fine-tuned to their local context including personal support (e.g., mentoring and scholarships), authentic scientific experiences (e.g., early start summer programs, academic year courses, and early research experiences), and student empowerment and community (e.g., student leadership roles, diversity workshops, and social activities), all of which support the sustained success of students from minoritized backgrounds in STEM by building community, sense of belonging, and positive science identities.

Access acknowledges that we must learn from marginalized people how to do equity and inclusion work well, and therefore create structures to support one another's learning. We engage in intentional, authentic collaboration with students in efforts to support their communities, which includes adapting resources, aligning programs, and changing Access itself to better fit their local sites' needs.

What has our organization accomplished in this three year period? The Access Network successfully held 3 Network-wide Assemblies, one in-person event and two synchronous virtual events. These events brought together 53 people in 2019, 64 people in 2020, 83 people in 2021, cumulatively reaching 133 unique participants. This grant supported 32 Assembly fellowships responsible for supporting the collaborative designing, planning, and running of Assembly sessions and activities (reaching 28 unique students). At our Assemblies, student leaders expand their toolkit for reflecting, organizing, and acting locally to address issues of diversity, equity, and inclusion in STEM. Many past attendees have appreciated meeting like-minded people that are also committed to tackling these issues and have found engaging with the Access community to relieve the strain of isolation that some students experience in STEM departments.

This grant also supported 41 Network communication fellowships responsible for facilitating communication between local sites and Network leaders, representing their site in Network decision making, and collaborating on projects (reaching 29 unique students). 

Through this grant, we also substantially expanded our Network's capacity by developing new organizational processes, expanding our central leadership team of Core Organizers (COs), and developing new capacities in our leaders. Our Network convened two task forces specifically focused on developing equitable processes for (1) expanding to new sites and (2) recruiting, selecting, and onboarding new COs. We onboarded 4 new COs, re-instilling student representation within our central leadership team. Lastly, we expanded COs' capacities for contributing to various core Network activities. For example, 5 COs newly took on mentorship of Network Fellows, and 4 COs and Network alumni newly took on mentorship of Assembly Fellows (in collaboration with experienced COs). The Network Ombuds team also participated in team training on conflict resolution led by professionals at the Rochester Institute of Technology. 

Evaluation activities were led in collaboration with student leaders through formative feedback collected at Assemblies and internal studies conducted on how our student leaders are shaped by their experiences in the Network (Amezcua, Quan, & Turpen, 2020). 

What impact has the Assess Network had? 

Broader Impacts. 53 unique student leaders and 133 unique Assembly participants were directly impacted by the work of the Network and are now leaders of collectivist approaches to equity and inclusion work in the physical sciences. These leaders will only continue to grow in their prominence and influence. These student leaders are shaping the lives of students in their sites, and alumni of Access continue to take Access innovations into new professional settings. We see clear evidence of culture change within robust subcommunities in these STEM departments and workplaces. Additionally, the Network developed a substantive emergency fund that supported some of our community members' unmet basic needs during the Covid-19 pandemic.

Intellectual Merit. The Access Network has established itself as a national leader in supporting multi-institutional, student-led equity work in the physical sciences as demonstrated by its recognition across multiple national reports. The AAAS Levers for Change report pointed to Access as one of the few examples of multi-institutional efforts to address equity. Access was also named as a key resource for student leaders in AIP TEAM-UP's The Time is Now report. The Access Network was highlighted in the 2016 Phys21 J-TUPP report from APS and AAPT as part of their recommendation to support student-led learning communities. Additionally, Access members have published nine journal articles and five conference papers on sites and two conference papers on the Network. Finally, Access members have given 38 presentations about the Network or sites at regional and national conferences, as well as five colloquia.
